text:
At about 35 kilometers long, Loch Ness is
the largest lake along the Great Glen, a geological

fault line that bisects Scotland. Of course
it’s also known for its most infamous resident—the

Loch Ness monster. Nicknamed Nessie, the rumored
creature is most often described with a small

head on a long, sinuous neck with a thick
body, seal-like flippers, and a long tail.
It almost looks prehistoric.

Water-dwelling monsters have long been established
in Scottish folklore. Scottish legends include

such water beasts as a giant, flesh-eating
waterfowl (boobrie), the shape-shifting water

horse (kelpie), and the nine-eyed eel (buarach-bhaoi),
but there are no folklore or literary records

that make mention of any of these monsters
exclusively inhabiting Loch Ness—until Nessie

Who doesn’t want to believe that there is
some yet undiscovered species that’s been

hiding away for all these years, or better
yet, a living dinosaur?

Understanding the legend of the Loch Ness
monster requires looking into hundreds of

years of lake reports, elaborate hoaxes, the
life of a saint, and… King Kong?
[Monstrum intro.]

It’s worth noting that the actual Loch Ness
in the Scottish Highlands is an ideal atmosphere

for monsters. Created from long-gone glaciers
the lake is deep and murky--making it hard

to see anything clearly. Fog and rain are
common, further obscuring views of the lake.
It’s beautiful, and mysterious.

Maybe that’s part of the reason why explanations
of the creature varied dramatically over time.

A lot of theories try to explain the Loch
Ness Monster. A lot. Possible explanations

include—I better take a deep breath for
this—swans, geological activity that shifts

the water’s surface, odd boat wakes, giant
catfish, giant sturgeon fish, some kind of

giant mammal relative to seals, sharks, whales,
a dinosaur, tunnels under the lake that lead

to the sea, the supernatural, or misplaced
ancient marine animal.

Nessie’s most reported form is an aquatic
creature with a long neck and flippers, though

some eyewitnesses have said it resembled a
sea serpent or a crocodile.

But before we get into the eyewitness accounts,
and how many were ultimately disproved, we

need to go back much further in history—to
the 6th century CE and the rumored life of

a saint. St. Columba was an Irish monk who
traveled as a missionary to Scotland in 563

CE. Almost a century later, a biography written
about his work in Scotland includes a story

of Columba encountering a “water beast”
at Loch Ness in 565 CE. The tale says Columba

encountered a group of locals burning the
body of a man they said had been “snatched”

and “mauled” by a “water beast” while
swimming.

Some people cite this encounter as the first
Loch Ness monster sighting, which would trace
the legend back 1,400 years.

Fast forward to 1817, and newspapers like
the San Francisco Call and the Coventry Evening

Telegraph printed stories about “sea serpents,”
with multiple reports continuing year after

year. The 19th century also saw the field
of Geology flourish, and as fossils resembling

these “sightings” turned up, so did speculation
that sea serpents were real-- sparking a debate

that questioned how long dinosaurs lived and
if they might still linger in the present
day.

In 1822 Loch Ness became part of the Caledonian
Canal, a route that opened coast to coast

travel and shipping. The canal expanded tourism
dramatically - and with daily steamship traffic

there was also a rise in reports of sea serpents
and other strange creatures living in Loch

Ness, solidifying this creature’s place
in Scottish folklore.

These sightings likely informed later tales
of the Loch Ness creature. Even back then,

one common theory to explain these sightings
was the survival of a prehistoric marine creature

or its descendant. Interestingly, mentions
of the Plesiosaurs were included in science

fiction of the 19th and 20th centuries as
well - in stories like Jules Verne’s Journey

to the Center of the Earth and Sir Arthur
Conan Doyle’s The Lost World. Both of these

books are about the discovery of secret worlds
on Earth, worlds where ancient life has been

preserved. It’s the same appeal that makes
movies like Jurassic Park so popular even

today--we want to hold on to the possibility
that we could encounter living versions of
the fossils we discover.

Nessie didn’t really get global attention
until the 1930s--coinciding with the Great

Depression. With morale low and reality so
distressing, stories of the mysterious creature
appealed to the desire for escapism many craved.

One particular newspaper report grabbed the
public’s attention.

Three anglers fishing for trout in Loch Ness
reported to the Northern Chronicle in 1930

that they heard “terrible noise” and saw
the water oddly moving as something approached

them in a “wriggling motion” that caused
a wave to rock their boat. As far as witness

accounts go, not too significant. But, this
is the first account that associated the creature

with the word “monster.” The article read,
“a wave 2½ feet high caused by some unknown

monster that, presumably, inhabits Loch Ness.”
Two other newspapers would later retell the
story using “monster” as well.

Following this, reports of the creature continued
to increase dramatically throughout the 30’s.

In 1933, reporter Alex Campbell wrote in the
Inverness Courier about a creature spotted

in Loch Ness (“Strange Spectacle on Loch
Ness: What Was It?”). The story claimed

John and Aldie [Mac-eye] a “well-known businessman”
and his wife, saw a creature “rolling and

plunging” in the water. They said it resembled
a whale and disappeared in a “boiling mass

of foam.” Aldie Mac-eye described the creature
as having two humps and a total body length
of around 6 meters.

The article stated “Loch Ness has for generations
been credited with being the home of a fearsome-looking

monster.” Campbell also retold the “three
angler” story from three years prior with

much more exaggerated, and quite frankly,
false detail. Neither account was taken very

seriously by locals, including steamship captain
John Macdonald. With over 50 years traveling

in the Loch, he said he had never seen anything
strange, adding that what the couple had described

was likely “sporting salmon in a lively
mood” leaping out of the water.

The first supposed photo of Nessie was taken
by Hugh Gray in November of 1933. In his words,

the photo showed “an object that rose two
or three feet above the surface of the water,”

and he considered it a sighting of the monster.
Analysis of the photograph led people to argue

that you could possibly see the rest of the
creature underwater. While the photo was believed

to be authentic, there was no way to clearly
identify what was actually being pictured.

But the photo added gas to the debate of whether
or not something was lurking deep in the waters

of Loch Ness. Scientific journals began publishing
articles about its rumored existence. The

first of these appeared, in Nature, just a
month after Gray’s photo, which the article

cites as “recent evidence,” also claiming
that “several observers have ‘seen’

an eel-like monster with humps on its back,
a creature with a small head and long neck

attached to an enormous body, and others something
that looked like an upturned boat.” The

reporter mentions that he spent half a day
on the Loch in July and saw nothing. Got to
love 1930s investigative journalism.

Nevertheless, articles of the time continued
to propose explanations for the sightings,

which have been debated for decades: Let’s
add even more to that list of possible explanations:

large eel, grampus, porpoise, whale-shark,
seal, otter, a sunfish, crocodile, Plesiosaurus,

and the sea-serpent of the Middle Age, “an
unstable mass of drifting peat,” or “a
white whale or beluga.”

When the Secretary of State for Scotland was
asked what was being done about the creature

the Secretary replied he was in contact with
the Chief Constable of Inverness-shire who

already had five constables stationed around
the loch, none of whom had seen the monster,

emphasizing that the creature “is guaranteed
protection should it appear and be threatened.”

Again that longing for wonder takes precedence--no
one wants the mysterious creature to be killed,

they want the possibility to see it alive
for themselves. Saving Nessie becomes more

important than trying to kill the monster
for “proof”—which can’t be said for
other monsters like the Yeti or the chupacabras.

Yet the Loch Ness Monster might not have solidified
its place in history without the help of another
giant beast—King Kong.

The 1933 movie King Kong made the giant ape
famous, and introduced a massive, long-neck

water monster to the screen. The film opened
in London on April 17, just two weeks before

Mac-eye’s famous sighting. Part of the action
on screen depicts a Brontosaurus who attacks

humans in the water before chasing one up
a tree and crushing it in its jaws.

Effectively, the movie reinforced the thesis
that prehistoric animals could be secretly

inhabiting the earth, and Nessie was one of
them.

A few months later on August 4, 1933, another
monster report appeared in the Inverness Courier.

While driving along the shore of Loch Ness
with his wife, a London man named George Spicer

spotted, in broad daylight, “the nearest
approach to a dragon or prehistoric animal”
crossing the road.

A sketch drawn from Spicer’s description
produced this image—which looks familiar…
(show King Kong clip again).

Because of George Spicer’s report and King
Kong, the “plesiosaur hypothesis” became

the dominant theory of the 20thcentury. Finally,
the creature had a recognizable face to its
name.

In early 1934, Nature published another article
responding to the supposed evidence up to

that point claiming with “little doubt”
the creature was in fact a large grey seal.

But every time a Loch Ness monster theory
is “debunked,” either another appears

or someone makes an effort to reestablish
doubt, making the waters murky again.

In November 1933 British naval officer and
author Rupert Gould, who wrote and published

his book The Case for the Sea Serpent in 1930,
went to Scotland to search for the creature.

He heard of the eyewitness accounts around
Loch Ness and immediately drew a connection

between them and the other creatures he had
researched. After months of gathering eyewitness

reports, he concluded there was indeed something
in the water, although he was unsure what

exactly. He published his findings in The
Loch Ness Monster and Others in 1934, which

was one of the first books dedicated to theories
of the myth.

It is now that we arrive at what you all probably
think of as “proof” that the Loch Ness
Monster exists: The “Surgeon's Photograph.”

The photo was given to newspapers by British
surgeon, Colonel Robert Wilson and published

April 21, 1934. The dark wide body, thin,
long neck and small head seem to come straight

from the Jurassic era—and the legend was
cemented in history.

Nessie went mainstream, and began to pop up
in campaigns for Scottish products, and was

given both male and female names like Sandy
and Archibald.

Between the newspaper accounts, the book,
the photographs, and the first Loch Ness movie,

The Secret of the Loch, the myth of the Loch
Ness monster became so popular that Scotland’s

official Travel Association had to go on record
denying they invented the stories to encourage
tourism…but still the legend grew.

The Linnean Society of London convened to
discuss the Loch Ness monster in 1934, aiming

to assess if the myth had any basis in truth.
Many thought it was a seal or cetacean [ce-tay-shen]

mammal of some kind. One scientist remained
convinced it was an otter. They also believed

it was “hopeless” to compare the creature
to any Mesozoic reptile due to lack of fossil
evidence.

After this, Loch Ness fervor seemed to die
down until a new photograph appeared in 1951.

Forester Lachlan Stuart captured a three-humped
version of the monster he said had been bobbing
its head and neck up and down in the water.

But, it didn’t take much time for him to
admit the hoax. He soon admitted the image

was really of three partially covered bales
of hay he placed in the water.

In 1957, Constance Whyte’s More Than a Legend
proposed that the Loch Ness monster isn’t

a singular creature but multiple sightings
of descendents of marine creatures that entered

the loch after the last Ice Age. Trapped in
the remains of a glacier, she proposed that

the ancestors of Nessie adapted to the fresh
water that over time turned the salt-water
loch into a fresh-water one.

For 20 years the legend of Nessie continued
undisturbed, fascinating people and building
lore around an unknown creature.

Then in 1975, the validity of the famous “Surgeon’s
Photograph” was called into question. A

man by the name of Ian Wetherell stepped forward
and claimed that his father faked the famous
photograph.

Back in 1933 journalist and big-game hunter
Marmaduke Wetherell was employed by the Daily

Mail to investigate the monster. He photographed
what he claimed to be “Nessie footprints.”

Zoologists revealed the footprints were from
the leg of a taxidermy hippopotamus.

Ian claimed his father was so upset that the
Nessie footprints weren’t well received

(or believed), as an act of vengeance he created
the Surgeon’s photograph. He staged the

photo using a toy submarine with a head made
from wood putty constructed by Ian himself

and his step brother. He gave it to a fellow
prankster who passed it along to his friend

Colonel Wilson who gave it to the press. In
1990, Ian’s step brother Christian Spurling,
confirmed the whole thing was fake.

Still, some people held onto the hope that
something strange was in Loch Ness.

The debate to formally preserve Nessie’s
survival began to take shape with believers

arguing that the creature should be a part
of the Conservation of Wild Creatures and

Wild Plants Act of 1975. The act protected
any animal whose survival is threatened—but

only if the animal has a scientific and a
common name. Scientists argued that despite

no conclusive proof Nessie exists, two photographs
taken in 1972 and 1975 left its existence

up for debate—so they gave the creature
a formal name [show Nessiteras rhombopteryx].

Part of the name [Nessiteras] adopts the name
of the lake and combines it with the Greek

word ‘teras’ - which means “marvel”
or “wonder,” and is often associated with

monsters. This part [rhombopteryx] combines
the Greek words for diamond and fin or wing.

So the name roughly translates to Ness monster
with diamond fin.

Unsurprisingly, even with a proper scientific
name, no conclusive evidence of any such creature

emerged. In fact, theories disproving the
legend became more advanced as technology
evolved.

In 2019, Professor Neil Gemmell, a New Zealand
geneticist led a project intended to catalogue

all the living species in Loch Ness using
DNA analysis.

None of the 500 million DNA sequences from
250 samples of Loch Ness water showed any

evidence of plesiosaur or other “Jurassic
reptile” and no catfish or sturgeon DNA,
which also eliminated those theories.

But he did find significant amounts of eel
DNA. Although Gemmell says that their data

does not give any information about the size
of the eels, he speculates there could be

giant eels in the Loch. However, locals insist
eels are nothing new in the lake —meaning

they can’t be the cause of the sightings
over the years. Some people also claim the

giant eel theory is unfounded since no side-to-side
movement from the creature has ever been reported.

More evidence piled up that the “Jurassic”
or “Plesiosaur theory” is untrue—no

fossil evidence has been found and multiple
sonar scans of the lake showed no existence
of any large aquatic creatures.

Even so, on average 10 unexplained creature
sightings on Loch Ness are reported every
year.

I think we want to believe that even in the
midst of so much scientific discovery and

advancement that there is something unknown,
something hidden in the world still. The fact

that science hasn’t ruled out the possibility
entirely is what’s exciting. Amateur researchers,

monster hunters, and everyday people alike
would love to be the first to prove Nessie
is real.

There’s an element of wonder and excitement
that comes from believing in the impossible—so

eyewitness reports continue and stories of
Nessie are shared, even as each one before
it is debunked.

The Loch Ness monster isn’t a monster that
inspires fear, it inspires wonder. It’s

a legend—a series of stories told and retold
to inspire astonishment and curiosity.
